items.title: JavaScript sans build systems?
items.content:
#â€‹626 â€” February 17, 2023

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Writing JavaScript Without a Build System â€” Using a variety of build tools for things like bundling and transpiling is reasonably standard in modern JavaScript development, but what if you want to keep things simple? For simple things, itâ€™s not necessary, says Julia. This led to a lot of discussion on HackerÂ News.

Julia Evans

Ryan Dahl, Node.js Creator, Wants to Rebuild the Runtime of the Web â€” A neat bit of journalism about the alternative JavaScript runtime Deno and what Ryan Dahl is trying to achieve with it and how Ryan handled the stress of being known as the creator ofÂ Node.js.

Harry Spitzer / Sequoia

Broadcasting a Live Stream With Nothing butÂ JavaScript â€” Live streams typically use third-party software to broadcast, but with Amazon Interactive Video Service, you can build a powerful, interactive broadcasting interface with the Web Broadcast SDK and JavaScript. Click here to learnÂ more.

Amazon Web Services (AWS) sponsor

core-js's Maintainer Complains Open Source Is 'Broken' â€” core-js is a popular universal polyfill for JavaScript features and its author has run into his fair share of bad luck which has culminated in this lengthy post on the state of the project, his issues in securing an income and, well, the downsides to living in Russia. The Register has tried to balance out theÂ story.

The Register

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ’ The just released Firefox 110 for Android now supports Tampermonkey, an extension for running JavaScript 'userscripts' on sites you visit.

  • The Angular project is taking steps to revamp its reactivity model to enable fine-grained change detection via signals.

  • The latest beta of iOS and iPadOS 16.4 supports the Web Push API for home screenÂ webapps.

  • ğŸ¦ A fun Twitter thread where Qwik's MiÅ¡ko Hevery attempted to demonstrate why a = 0-x is about 3-10x faster than a = -x before being told about a flaw in his benchmark. There is still a performance difference, though.

  • â–¶ï¸ The React.js documentary we mentioned last week has now been released and it's a heck of a watch â€“ you'll need 78 minutes of your timeÂ though.

RELEASES:

  • Node.js 19.6.1, 18.14.1, 16.19.1 and 14.21.3.

  • JavaScript Obfuscator 4.0 â€“ Code scrambler.

  • Shoelace 2.1
    â†³ Framework agnostic Web components.

  • Mermaid 9.4
    â†³ Text to diagram generator. Now with timeline diagram support.

  • Cypress 12.6

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Use a MutationObserver to Handle DOM Nodes that Donâ€™t Exist Yet â€” Comparing the effectiveness of the MutationObserver API with the conventional method of constantly checking for the creation ofÂ nodes.

Alex MacArthur

Well-Known Symbols in JavaScript â€” Hemanth, a TC39 delegate, shows off 14 symbols and where they can come inÂ useful.

Hemanth HM

ğŸš€ Monitor and Optimize Website Speed to Rank Higher in Google â€” Monitor Google's Core Web Vitals and optimize performance using in-depth reports built for developers. Improve SEO &Â UX.

DebugBear sponsor

Why to Use Maps More and Objects Less â€” A journey down a performance rabbitÂ hole.

Steve Sewell

Adopting React in the Early Days â€” A personal history lesson providing context around Reactâ€™s evolution. While React might be an obvious, even safe, choice now, that wasnâ€™t alwaysÂ true.

SÃ©bastien Lorber

An Animated Flythrough with Theatre.js and React Three Fiber â€” How to fly through a 3D scene using the Theatre.js JavaScript animation library and the React Three Fiber 3D renderer. This is the sort of thing that used to be Very Difficultâ„¢ but is now relativelyÂ trivial.

Andrew Prifer (Codrops)

How to Change the Tab Bar Color Dynamically with JavaScript
Amit Merchant

Is Deno Ready for Primetime? One Dev's Opinion
Max Countryman

Using Playwright to Monitor Third-Party Resources That Could Impact User Experience
Stefan Judis

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Dependency Cruiser: Validate and Visualize JavaScript Dependencies â€” If you want a look at the output, thereâ€™s a whole page of graphs for popular, real world projects including Chalk, Yarn, andÂ React.

Sander Verweij

Devalue: Like JSON.stringify, But.. â€” â€œGets the job done when JSON.stringify canâ€™t.â€ Namely, it can handle cyclical and repeated references, regular expressions, Map and Set, custom types, andÂ more.

Rich Harris

ğŸ§¡ JavaScript Scratchpad for VS Code (2m+ Downloads) â€” Get Quokka.js 'Community' for free: #1 tool for exploring/testing JavaScript with edit-continue experience to see realtime execution and runtimeÂ values.

Wallaby.js sponsor

NodeGUI: Build Native Cross-Platform Desktop Apps with Node.js â€” Unlike Electron which leans upon webviews and HTML, NodeGui uses a Qt based approach. This weekâ€™s 0.58.0 release is the first stable release based on Qt 6 and offering high DPIÂ support.

NodeGui

DOMPurify 3.0: Fast, Tolerant XSS Sanitizer for HTML and SVG â€” A project thatâ€™s nine years old today but still actively developed. Supports all modern browsers (IE support was only just dropped) and is heavily tested. Thereâ€™s a live demoÂ here.

Cure53

Pythagora: Generate Express Integration Tests by RecordingÂ Activity â€” This is a neat idea still in its early stages. Add a line of code after setting up an Express.js app and this will capture app usage and generate integration tests based on the interactions. (â–¶ï¸ ScreencastÂ demo.)

zvone187 and LeonOstrez

Try Streamâ€™s Free Trial of SDKs for In-App Chat

Stream sponsor

grep.app: Search Code Across a Half Million GitHub Repos â€” A code search engine that lets you use regexes or syntax in your search. Considering what it is, itâ€™s pretty fast and has an extensive index (over half a million public repos from GitHub, allegedly).

grep.app

tsParticles: Particles, Confetti and Fireworks for Your Pages â€” Create customizable particle related effects for use on the Web. Uses the regular 2D canvas for broadÂ support.

Matteo Bruni

ğŸ’» Jobs

Software Engineer â€” Join our happy team. Stimulus is a social platform started by Sticker Mule to show what's possible if your mission is to increase humanÂ happiness.
Stimulus

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profileÂ now.
Hired

QUICK RELEASES:

  • Minimatch 6.2
    â†³ Glob matcher library, as used in npm.
    Â Â Â Â minimatch("bar.foo", "*.foo")

  • React Accordion 1.2
    â†³ Unstyled WAI-ARIA-compliant accordion library.

  • ScrollTrigger 1.0.6
    â†³ Have your page react to scroll changes.

  • VeeValidate 4.7.4
    â†³ Popular Vue.js form library

  • Express Admin 2.0
    â†³ Admin interface for data in MySQL/Postgres/SQLite.

  • Execa 7.0
    â†³ Improved process execution from Node.js.

  • React Tooltip 5.8

items.title: Bringing JavaScript to WebAssembly
items.content:
#â€‹625 â€” February 10, 2023

Read on the Web

It looked quiet at first but wow, what an epic week this turned out to be. There's a lot to chew on here, and we even have a variety of bonus items at the very end of the issue.Â Enjoy!
__
Your editor, Peter Cooper

JavaScript Weekly

Speeding Up the JS Ecosystem: It's ESLint's Turn â€” Last year we featured an article from the same author about how he was finding, and fixing, low-hanging performance fruit in popular JavaScript projects. Heâ€™s back, and heâ€™s found a lot of potential for savings in ESLint thisÂ time.

Marvin Hagemeister

The Future (and the Past) of the Web is Server Side Rendering â€” Itâ€™s fair to say the Deno folks have some skin in this game, but nonetheless this is a neat brief history of server-side rendering and why they feel itâ€™s the right approach for modern webÂ development.

Andy Jiang (Deno)

Monitoring Your NestJS Application withÂ AppSignal â€” With AppSignal, you can monitor your NestJS app with ease and rely on OpenTelemetry to handle third-party instrumentations. AppSignal even provides helper functions to help you build comprehensive custom instrumentation. A box of ğŸªÂ included!

AppSignal sponsor

Ten Web Development Trends in 2023 â€” Following the State of JS survey results Robin takes a considered look at new web dev trends that we should be paying attention to this year, and why theyÂ matter.

Robin Wieruch

Bringing JavaScript to WebAssembly for Shopify Functions â€” As much as this is focused on a specific use case at Shopify, this is a fascinating look at how theyâ€™re integrating JavaScript and WebAssembly under tight constraints. They also talk about Javy, a JS to WebAssembly toolchain being built at Shopify that lets you run JS code on a WASM-embedded JSÂ runtime.

Surma (Shopify)

Google Touts Web-Based Machine Learning with TensorFlow.js
Richard MacManus (The New Stack)

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ‰ Time to celebrate â€” a recent survey allegedly found that JavaScript applications 'have fewer flaws' than Java and .NET ones. So there youÂ go.

  • Honeypot's highly anticipated â–¶ï¸ React.js documentary drops later today â€“ it'll probably be out by the time you read this.

  • Vanilla List is a directory of 'vanilla' JavaScript controls and plugins.

  • â–¶ï¸ Evan You tells us what to expect in 2023 from Vue.js.

  • The Scala.js project is celebrating its ten year anniversary â€“ it's now a mature way to build Web projects using Scala, if youÂ prefer.

  • ğŸ“… Vue.js Live is a JavaScript event taking place both in London and online on May 12 & 15. From the same folks as the also forthcoming JSNation conference.

  • A history of criticisms levelled at React.

RELEASES:

  • Eleventy / 11ty 2.0
    â†³ Popular Node.js static site generator.

  • pnpm 7.27 â€“ The efficient package manager.

  • RxDB 14.0 â€“ Offline-first, reactive database.

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Design Patterns in TypeScript â€” OO-inspired patterns arenâ€™t for everyone or every use case, but this is a fantastic catalog of examples, complete with diagrams and explanations, if you need to learn to tell apart factory methods from decorators, facades, orÂ proxies.

Refactoring Guru

Resumable React: How To Use React Inside Qwik â€” Building React apps without ever loading React in the userâ€™s browser? â€œSounds too good to be true? Letâ€™s see how thisÂ works.â€

Yoav Ganbar

Did You Know That You're Already a Distributed Systems Developer?

Temporal Technologies sponsor

Build a Hacker News Client using Alpine.js â€” Alpine.js is a thin and elegant reactivity library that lets you add dynamic functionality to your site directly in markup. This is a short and sweet practical example of what you can quickly do withÂ it.

Salai Vedha Viradhan

â–¶Â Â TypeScript Speedrun: A Crash Course for Beginners â€” If you want to pick up TypeScript and would find a video guide useful, this is for you. Matt has become well known recently for his educational TypeScript tweets and videos, and this is another good one that flies through the basics. (23Â minutes.)

Matt Pocock

Using Notion as a Headless CMS with Nuxt
Trent Brew

The Options API vs Composition API in Vue.js
Charles Allotey

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Bookmarklet Editor: Easily Work on JavaScript Bookmarklets â€” Useful because who can remember the exact syntax for a bookmarklet? ğŸ¤” This also can instantly convert code to and from bookmarklet form and includes some examples in the help section (click the big ? to get all theÂ details).

Marek Gibney

Breakpoints and console.log Is the Past, Time Travel Is the Future â€” 15x faster JavaScript debugging than with breakpoints and console.log, now with support forÂ Vitest.

Wallaby.js sponsor

Yup 1.0: Super Simple Object Schema Validation â€” Define a schema, transform a value to match, assert the shape of an existing value, or both. Very extensive docsÂ here.

Jason Quense

Material React Table: A Full-Featured React Table Component â€” Built upon Material UI 5 and TanStack Table 8. The docs include lots of interactiveÂ examples.

Kevin Van Cott

BlockNote: Notion-Style Block-Based Text Editor â€” Built on top of Prosemirror and Tiptap, this is for you if you like the way the Notion note-taking serviceâ€™s text editor feels. Thereâ€™s a liveÂ demo.

Yousef

TresJS: Build 3D Experiences with Vue.js â€” Create 3D scenes with Vue components and Three.js. Think React-three-fiber but VueÂ flavored.

Alvaro Sabu

depngn: Find Out if Dependencies Support a Given Node.js Version â€” A CLI tool that establishes whether or not the dependencies in your package.json will work against a specified version ofÂ Node.

OmbuLabs

Open-Source JS Form Libraries to Automate Your Form Workflow â€” Self-host SurveyJS to configure and modify multiple forms, convert them to fillable PDF files, and analyze collected data in interactiveÂ dashboards.

SurveyJS sponsor

Lawnmower: Build VR Scenes with Custom HTML Tags â€” A web component library that leans on Three.js and aims â€œto make building a basic VR website as easy to make as your first HTMLÂ siteâ€.

Gareth Marland

Electron 23.0 Released â€” The popular cross platform JavaScript, HTML + CSS desktop app framework gets bumped up to Node 18.12.1, Chromium 110, and V8 11.0. Windows 7/8/8.1 support has also been dropped, so we might start to see those versions of Windows lose the support of a lot of Electron based appsÂ soon.

Electron Core Team

Run: Run User-Provided Code in a Web Worker

SLASHD Analytics

ğŸ’» Jobs

Software Engineer (Backend) â€” Join our "kick ass" team. Our software team operates from 17 countries and we're always looking for more exceptionalÂ engineers.
Sticker Mule

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profileÂ now.
Hired

QUICK RELEASES:

  • vue-easytable 2.23
    â†³ A data table/grid control for Vue.js. (Demo.)

  • React-Custom-Scroll 5.0
    â†³ Customize the browser scroll bar. (Demo.)

  • react-jsonschema-form 5.1
    â†³ Component to build Web forms from JSON Schema.

  • AlaSQL.js 3.1
    â†³ JavaScript-based SQL database.

  • jest-puppeteer 7.0
    â†³ Run tests using Jest & Puppeteer.

  • MDX 2.3
    â†³ Markdown for the component era.

ğŸÂ The Bonus Round

  • âœˆï¸ Watching someone wrestle with Python and JavaScript to fly (virtual) planes with Microsoft Flight Simulator tickled me a lot.

  • A beautiful WebGL2-based fluid simulation. It's even happy on mobile.Â Pretty!

  • Go-like channels in 10 lines of JavaTypeScript..?

  • ğŸ¦ Misko Hevery: "useSignal() is the future of web frameworks and is a better abstraction than useState(), which is showing its age." (source)

  • Mike Pennisi asks: when is an object property not a property?

  • Do you use Postgres at all? Check out Postgres Weekly â€“ one of our sister newsletters. So much is going on in the Postgres space lately and it's a great way to keep up.

âœˆï¸ Watching someone wrestle with Python and JavaScript to fly (virtual) planes with Microsoft Flight Simulator tickled me a lot.
A beautiful WebGL2-based fluid simulation. It's even happy on mobile.Â Pretty!
Go-like channels in 10 lines of JavaTypeScript..?
ğŸ¦ Misko Hevery: "useSignal() is the future of web frameworks and is a better abstraction than useState(), which is showing its age." (source)

Do you use Postgres at all? Check out Postgres Weekly â€“ one of our sister newsletters. So much is going on in the Postgres space lately and it's a great way to keep up.

items.title: Ways to remove event listeners
items.content:
#â€‹624 â€” February 3, 2023

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Youâ€™ve Got Options for Removing EventÂ Listeners â€” Unnecessary event listeners can cause all sorts of odd problems so itâ€™s good to clean them up when you donâ€™t need them anymore. How? There are several approaches and Alex looks at their pros and cons. (once is a good one to consider if your use case supports it as itâ€™s â€˜set andÂ forget.â€™)

Alex MacArthur

Updates from the 94th TC39 meeting â€” The TC39 committee that works on the ECMAScript standard met last week and progressed a few language proposals with Change Array by Copy, Intl.NumberFormat v3 and Symbols as WeakMap Keys making it to stage 4. Thereâ€™s also an interesting example of a downgrade to stage 2 for importÂ assertions.

Hemanth HM

Fast and Flexible Gantt Chart Components for Your WebÂ App â€” Bryntum's suite of web components includes powerful Gantt and resource scheduling widgets used by thousands of businesses. The API is very flexible and allows you to configure everything from colors to details of the scheduling logic. Free 45-dayÂ trial.

Bryntum sponsor

Netlify Acquires Gatsby â€” The company behind the Gatsby React-based framework is joining Netlify with many Gatsby Cloud features expected to be integrated into Netlifyâ€™s own platform. This places Netlify more directly against Vercel who are behindÂ Next.js (and don't forget Shopify with RemixÂ too).

Kyle Mathews (Gatsby)

You May Not Need Lodash or Underscore â€” Inspired by the popular You Might Not Need jQuery, this extensive document provides plain JavaScript alternatives to almost 100 different functions youâ€™d find in popular utility libraries like Lodash and Underscore.

You Don't Need

The Future of Create React App and Why It Exists â€” An extensive write up from Dan Abramov on the state of Create React App, a route to take it forwards, and how he sees React as a library working within an ecosystem ofÂ frameworks.

Dan Abramov

RELEASES:

  • Node.js v19.6.0 (Current)

  • Node.js v18.14.0 (LTS)

  • Electron 22

  • TestCafe 2.3
    â†³ End-to-end Web testing.

  • Docusaurus 2.3
    â†³ Popular documentation site generator.

  • Jotai 2.0

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

How To Lose Functional Programming atÂ Work â€” An amusing piece you might recognize parts of. It's certainly possible to have too much of a good thing. â€œIf youâ€™re looking to lose functional programming at work, here are a bunch of mistakes Iâ€™ve made on JS-heavy web teams over the years that can help you doÂ theÂ same.â€

Robert Pearce

How Node & SWC Can Make a Lightning Fast TypeScript Runtime â€” If the added compilation time for TypeScript has irritated you so far, Artem has found a way to get things as fast asÂ possible.

Artem Avetisyan

â–¶Â Â Tailwind CSS, Headless UI, and Powerlifting with Adam Wathan â€” We talk to Adam about what motivated him to create Tailwind and why it is creating polarizing discourse amongÂ developers.

Whiskey Web and Whatnot sponsorpodcast

The Road from Ember Classic to Glimmer Components â€” If youâ€™ve got a mature Ember.js project you want to modernize, this is forÂ you.

Ignace Maes

Using JavaScript in a Swift App â€” One for iOS app developers. Itâ€™s not perfect but at least itâ€™s anÂ option.

Douglas Hill

Cleaner Unit Tests with Custom Matchers â€” Using custom matchers to avoid repetitive and ambiguous assertions inÂ Jest.

Jamie King (American Express)

The Yaml Document from Hell: JSÂ Edition â€” The titular problematic document was spawned in this blog post focusing on Python, but Phil looks to see if JS YAML parsers have the same problems with the much malignedÂ format.

Phil Nash

Too Much Tech Debt and Outdated Packages? Don't Have Time toÂ Upgrade?

UpgradeJS by OmbuLabs sponsor

On Using Playwright in GitHub Actions
RadosÅ‚aw Miernik

How I Made My App 2.4x Faster Switching to Svelte
Flotes Tech Blog

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

FeedbackPlus: Add Screenshot Tools to Your Feedback Forms â€” Say youâ€™ve got a form on your app to let users submit bugs or feedback and youâ€™d like to encourage them to send a screenshot too â€“ this makes it easier to do. LiveÂ demo.

ColonelParrot

â–¶Â Â ScrollyVideo.js: Responsive 'Scrollable'Â Videos â€” Itâ€™s an interesting effect and well demonstrated here. Compatible with React, Svelte, Vue, or just plain oleâ€™ HTML.

Daniel Kao

Stop Sweating Over Supply Chain Security withÂ Snyk â€” Get the security practices and tooling to bolster your build pipeline from Snykâ€™s article on npm security and preventing supply chainÂ attacks.

Snyk sponsor

depngn: Find Out if Dependencies Support a Given Node Version â€” A CLI tool that establishes whether dependencies in your package.json will work against a specified Node version. May be helpful duringÂ upgrades.

OmbuLabs

Eta 2.0: Embedded JS Template Engine for Node, Deno, and Browser â€” Boasts being lighter and faster than EJS but with many of the same features (it looks a lot like Rubyâ€™s ERB). GitHubÂ repo.

Ben Gubler

Swiper 9.0: Mobile Touch Slider with Accelerated Transitions â€” Tree shakable, library agnostic, and focused entirely on modern browsers and web APIs. RTL support too. GitHubÂ repo.

Vladimir Kharlampidi

UUID.js: RFC-Compliant UUID Generator â€” Supports v1 and v4Â UUIDs.

LiosK

  • ReScript 10.1
    â†³ OCaml-inspired compile-to-JS language.

  • OrgChart 3.4
    â†³ Render org charts. (Lots of demos.)

  • clipboard-polyfill 4.0
    â†³ 'Copy to clipboard' for older browsers and edgeÂ cases.

  • morphdom 2.7
    â†³ DOM diffing/patching â€“ no VDOMÂ needed.

  • relative-time-element 4.2
    â†³ GitHub's extensions forÂ <time>

  • js-bson 5.0
    â†³ Binary JSON parser and serialization.

  • React Date Picker 4.10
    â†³ Simple date picker React component.

  • JustValidate 4.1
    â†³ Lightweight form validation library.

ğŸ’» Jobs

Platform Engineer - Dev Ops â€” Come help Qwire modernize how studios, composers, artists, publishers, labels, and the rest of the industry manage musicÂ rights.
Qwire

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profileÂ now.
Hired

ğŸÂ Last But Not Least

Madge 6.0: Create Graphs From Your Module Dependencies â€” A developer tool for generating a visual graph of your module dependencies (works with CommonJS, AMD and ES modules), finding circular dependencies, and discovering other usefulÂ info.

Patrik Henningsson

items.title: Astro 2.0 and TypeScript 5.0 beta
items.content:
#â€‹623 â€” January 27, 2023

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Astro 2.0: The Next-Gen 'Islands'-Oriented Web Framework â€” 2.0 includes hybrid rendering (mixing of SSR and SSG outputs), type safety for Markdown & MDX, and an upgrade to Vite 4.0. Astro is worth exploring when performance is key as it works with popular frameworks but lets you deliver the least JS possible to get pagesÂ rendered.

Fred Schott

Prefer a talk? Nate Moore's ViteConf talk â–¶ï¸ Islands Architecture, Astro, and You will bring you up toÂ speed.

Deep Cloning Objects in JavaScript, The ModernÂ Way â€” If youâ€™ve been leaning on something like Lodash for deep cloning, you might not need to any longer. â€œItâ€™s been a long time coming, but we finally now have the built-in structuredClone function to make deep cloning objects in JavaScript aÂ breeze.â€

Steve Sewell

Go From Professional Web Developer to LeadÂ Engineer â€” Aspiring lead developer? Our collection of comprehensive video courses cover the fundamentals of JavaScript, TypeScript, React, web performance, andÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Announcing TypeScript 5.0 Beta â€” A new major version number, but users of the popular typed JS superset will face a â€˜similar upgrade experienceâ€™ to previously. Decorators make it in as a first class feature, significant performance and package size optimizations are present, export type * is supported, all enums are now union enums, and muchÂ more.

Daniel Rosenwasser (Microsoft)

AlaSQL.js 3.0: Isomorphic JavaScript SQLÂ Database â€” A SQL database you can use in the browser, Node.js or mobile apps. An interesting bit of functionality is you can use SQL to query JavaScript objects â€“ example. â€œThe library adds the comfort of a full database engine to your JavaScript app. No,Â really.â€

Andrey Gershun

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ… If you're really into Vue.js, you'll soon be able to become officially certified in it.

  • If you're using React, you should be using a React framework, ğŸ¦ says Andrew Clark of the core team.

  • The creator of alternative JS runtime Bun asks: "If there's one thing missing from Bun for you to switch, what is it?" You can reply on Twitter.

  • jQAPI.com is an amazing meeting of old and new JavaScript â€“ it's an Astro powered version of jQuery's documentation!

RELEASES:

  • Shoelace 2.0
    â†³ Agnostic library of webÂ components.

  • Î¼Fuzzy 1.0
    â†³ Tiny fuzzy search library.

  • React Router 6.8

  • Node.js 19.5.0

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Getting Started with SvelteKit â€” SvelteKit only recently hit 1.0 and this is a comprehensive overview of how to build a site using the Svelte-oriented app framework. It covers topics like routing, layouts, data, props andÂ more.

Adam Rackis

Using .NET Code from JavaScript using WebAssembly â€” â€œStarting with .NET 7, you can easily run any .NET method from JavaScript without needing the whole BlazorÂ framework.â€

GÃ©rald BarrÃ©

JavaScript Scratchpad for VS Code (2m+ Downloads) â€” Quokka.js is the #1 tool for exploring/testing JavaScript with edit-continue experience to see realtime execution and runtimeÂ values.

Wallaby.js sponsor

scrollend: A New JavaScript Event â€” Finally an event you wonâ€™t need a hotel booking for. scrollend provides a new way to detect that a scrolling operation is complete in the browser. Is it another Chrome-only nicety? Surprisingly not â€“ Firefox 109+ supports itÂ too.

Adam Argyle (Chrome Team)

Packaging Rust Apps for the npmÂ Registry â€” Isnâ€™t npm just for JavaScript projects? Nope. Node is required to make this technique work, but as long as you can package and execute a binary, youâ€™re good toÂ go.

Orhun ParmaksÄ±z

Making Sense of TypeScript using Set Theory â€” This article certainly doesnâ€™t hang around. Neat diagramsÂ too.

Vladimir Klepov

React Authentication, Simplified

Userfront sponsor

Accessible Hamburger Buttons without JavaScript â€” Sometimes you need to consider if modern techniques allow you to avoid JavaScript. Hereâ€™s a CodePen if you want toÂ play.

Pausly

While we're on the topic of less JavaScript, the latest episode of the Stack Overflow podcast â–¶ï¸ 'The less JavaScript, the better' focuses on Astro.

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Uppy 3.4: Powerful, Modular JavaScript File Uploader â€” Upload not just from local sources but even Dropbox or Instagram. Integrates with popular frameworks and supports resumable uploads. GitHubÂ repo.

Transloadit

Nut.js 3.0: Desktop Automation from Node â€” Take control of your desktop (Windows, macOS or Linux) in code with control over keyboard + pointer, along with image matching functionality. GitHubÂ repo.

Simon Hofmann

Optimize Your Systems' Performance With TelemetryHub - Real-Time Data Monitoring & Analysis â€” An advanced data visualization and analysis tool that can help you identify and resolve unseen issues in your environment. TryÂ free.

TelemetryHub by Scout sponsor

Eleventy v2.0: First Beta of the Popular SiteÂ Generator â€” Eleventy is a popular Node.js static site generator and v2.0 includes enough major changes that a thorough beta is needed. The creator â–¶ï¸ made this quick video about theÂ release.

Zach Leatherman

Mock Service Worker 1.0: API Mocking Library for Browser andÂ Node â€” Intercepts requests which you can then mock. Capture outgoing requests using an Express-like routing syntax, complete with parameters, wildcards, and regexes. GitHubÂ repo.

Artem Zakharchenko

Drift: A Self-Hostable Gist-Like / PastebinÂ Service â€” Built with Next.jsÂ 13.

Max Leiter

  • Dygraphs 2.2
    â†³ Interactive charts of time seriesÂ data.

  • actions/github-script 6.4
    â†³ Write GitHub Actions workflows inÂ JS.

  • Playwright 1.30
    â†³ Browser automation framework.

  • Faast.js 6.4
    â†³ Serverlessly call JS functions on AWS Lambda & GoogleÂ CloudÂ Functions.

  • Cypress 12.4
    â†³ Testing framework for anything in aÂ browser.

  • D3plus 2.1
    â†³ Extend D3.js with more visualizationÂ types.

ğŸ’» Jobs

Developer Relations Manager â€” Join the CKEditor team to build community around an Open Source project used by millions of users around the worldÂ ğŸš€
CKEditor

Senior Full-Stack Engineer - React + TypeScript â€” Come help Qwire modernize how studios, composers, artists, publishers, labels, and the rest of the industry manage musicÂ rights.
Qwire

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.
Hired

title: JavaScript Weekly
description: A newsletter of JavaScript articles, news and cool projects
